articles.headline: Hurt by Lockdowns, California’s Small Businesses Push to Recall Governor
articles.snippet: The pain for such enterprises been particularly acute in the state, leading some to back an effort to replace Gov. Gavin Newsom.
articles.abstract: The pain for such enterprises been particularly acute in the state, leading some to back an effort to replace Gov. Gavin Newsom.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Alexandra and Daniela Del Gaudio had never been to a political rally before, let alone one to protest a coronavirus lockdown and recall Gov. Gavin Newsom. But things had changed in the sisters’ lives since they opened the Wild Plum, a yoga and wellness space, in 2018.

articles.headline: Annie’s Pledges to Purge a Class of Chemicals From Its Mac and Cheese
articles.snippet: The move comes nearly four years after a study showed that chemicals believed to cause health problems in children and reproductive issues in adults were found in mass-market macaroni and cheese packets.
articles.abstract: The move comes nearly four years after a study showed that chemicals believed to cause health problems in children and reproductive issues in adults were found in mass-market macaroni and cheese packets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly four years after traces of chemicals believed to cause health problems in children and reproductive issues in adults were found in mass-market macaroni and cheese packets, Annie’s Homegrown has begun working with its suppliers to eliminate the offending material from their food processing equipment.

articles.headline: Erik Prince, Trump Ally, Violated Libya Arms Embargo, U.N. Report Says
articles.snippet: Mr. Prince offered to supply weapons, drones and mercenaries to a Libyan militia commander seeking to overthrow the government, according to U.N. investigators.
articles.abstract: Mr. Prince offered to supply weapons, drones and mercenaries to a Libyan militia commander seeking to overthrow the government, according to U.N. investigators.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Republicans Struggle to Derail Increasingly Popular Stimulus Package
articles.snippet: A $1.9 trillion rescue plan polls strongly across the country, including with many Republican voters, despite a scattershot series of attacks from congressional Republicans.
articles.abstract: A $1.9 trillion rescue plan polls strongly across the country, including with many Republican voters, despite a scattershot series of attacks from congressional Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans are struggling to persuade voters to oppose President Biden’s $1.9 trillion economic rescue plan, which enjoys strong, bipartisan support nationwide even as it is moving through Congress with just Democratic backing.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Extreme Cold Killed Texans in Their Bedrooms, Vehicles and Backyards
articles.snippet: At least 58 people died in storm-affected areas stretching to Ohio, victims of carbon monoxide poisoning, car crashes, drownings, house fires and hypothermia.
articles.abstract: At least 58 people died in storm-affected areas stretching to Ohio, victims of carbon monoxide poisoning, car crashes, drownings, house fires and hypothermia.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Carrol Anderson spent much of his life in Southeast Texas, where the most feared natural disasters spin up from the Gulf of Mexico during the warm months of hurricane season. But last week, Mr. Anderson, a 75-year-old who breathed with the help of oxygen tanks, knew that a different kind of storm was heading his way.
articles.byline: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Richard Fausset and Johnny Diaz

articles.headline: Biden Tells Allies ‘America Is Back,’ but Macron and Merkel Push Back
articles.snippet: All three leaders seemed to recognize, though, that their first virtual encounter was a moment to celebrate the end of the “America First” era.
articles.abstract: All three leaders seemed to recognize, though, that their first virtual encounter was a moment to celebrate the end of the “America First” era.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden used his first public encounter with America’s European allies to describe a new struggle between the West and the forces of autocracy, declaring that “America is back” while acknowledging that the past four years had taken a toll on its power and influence.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger and Roger Cohen

articles.headline: The Boredom Economy
articles.snippet: The pandemic is terrible. It can also be tedious. And that tedium is shaping what people buy and how productive they are.
articles.abstract: The pandemic is terrible. It can also be tedious. And that tedium is shaping what people buy and how productive they are.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Hawkins is an expert on being bored.

articles.headline: Where Will Rush Limbaugh’s 15 Million Listeners Go Now?
articles.snippet: No one will have a megaphone like his again. But podcasters, “26-year-old conservatives on Instagram” and Sean Hannity all fill the void.
articles.abstract: No one will have a megaphone like his again. But podcasters, “26-year-old conservatives on Instagram” and Sean Hannity all fill the void.
articles.lead_paragraph: So who now takes the place of Rush Limbaugh as the media ringmaster of the right?

articles.headline: Venezuelan Women Lose Access to Contraception, and Control of Their Lives
articles.snippet: Affordable birth control has disappeared, pushing many women into unplanned pregnancies at a time when they can barely feed the children they already have.
articles.abstract: Affordable birth control has disappeared, pushing many women into unplanned pregnancies at a time when they can barely feed the children they already have.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO DE LOS ALTOS, Venezuela — The moment Johanna Guzmán, 25, discovered she was going to have her sixth child she began to sob, crushed by the idea of bringing another life into a nation in such decay.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Isayen Herrera and Meridith Kohut

articles.headline: Merrick Garland Faces Resurgent Peril After Years Fighting Extremism
articles.snippet: The fallout from the Capitol attack and the shadow of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing are likely to take center stage at the confirmation hearings for President Biden’s pick for attorney general.
articles.abstract: The fallout from the Capitol attack and the shadow of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing are likely to take center stage at the confirmation hearings for President Biden’s pick for attorney general.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Merrick B. Garland always made a point of wearing a coat and tie when he surveyed the wreckage at the site of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing, the worst domestic terrorist attack in American history.

articles.headline: China Censors the Internet. So Why Doesn’t Russia?
articles.snippet: The Kremlin has constructed an entire infrastructure of repression but has not displaced Western apps. Instead, it is turning to outright intimidation.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin has constructed an entire infrastructure of repression but has not displaced Western apps. Instead, it is turning to outright intimidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Margarita Simonyan, the editor in chief of the Kremlin-controlled RT television network, recently called on the government to block access to Western social media.

articles.headline: A Ripple Effect of Loss: U.S. Covid Deaths Approach 500,000
articles.snippet: Twice as many Americans have died as early worst-case projections.
articles.abstract: Twice as many Americans have died as early worst-case projections.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A nation numbed by misery and loss is confronting a number that still has the power to shock: 500,000.

articles.headline: How Democrats Are Already Maneuvering to Shape Biden’s First Supreme Court Pick
articles.snippet: Party leaders are urging President Biden not only to consider racial diversity in potential Supreme Court nominees, but to look at candidates who don’t come from a traditional Ivy League background.
articles.abstract: Party leaders are urging President Biden not only to consider racial diversity in potential Supreme Court nominees, but to look at candidates who don’t come from a traditional Ivy League background.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After meeting in the Oval Office earlier this month with President Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris and his fellow senior House Democrats, Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina made a beeline to Ms. Harris’s office in the West Wing to privately raise a topic that did not come up during their group discussion: the Supreme Court.

articles.headline: How Texas’ Drive for Energy Independence Set It Up for Disaster
articles.snippet: Texas has refused to join interstate electrical grids and railed against energy regulation. Now it’s having to answer to millions of residents who were left without power in last week’s snowstorm.
articles.abstract: Texas has refused to join interstate electrical grids and railed against energy regulation. Now it’s having to answer to millions of residents who were left without power in last week’s snowstorm.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Across the plains of West Texas, the pump jacks that resemble giant bobbing hammers define not just the landscape but the state itself: Texas has been built on the oil-and-gas business for the last 120 years, ever since the discovery of oil on Spindletop Hill near Beaumont in 1901.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss, Manny Fernandez, Ivan Penn and Rick Rojas

articles.headline: Airbnb Is Driving Hosts Elsewhere With Costly Pandemic Policies
articles.snippet: Hurt by refunds, some are trying to cut the site out of bookings or taking legal action. The company says it is working to reduce tensions.
articles.abstract: Hurt by refunds, some are trying to cut the site out of bookings or taking legal action. The company says it is working to reduce tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over six years, Lorraine Luongo went from renting out a spare room in her house in Myrtle Beach, S.C., to owning and managing 10 properties that she listed on Airbnb.

articles.headline: On the Post-Pandemic Horizon, Could That Be … a Boom?
articles.snippet: Signs of economic life are picking up, and mounds of cash are waiting to be spent as the virus loosens its grip.
articles.abstract: Signs of economic life are picking up, and mounds of cash are waiting to be spent as the virus loosens its grip.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy remains mired in a pandemic winter of shuttered storefronts, high unemployment and sluggish job growth. But on Wall Street and in Washington, attention is shifting to an intriguing if indistinct prospect: a post-Covid boom.

articles.headline: How Investigative Journalism Flourished in Hostile Russia
articles.snippet: A new wave of news outlets has used conventional, and unconventional, methods to pierce the veil of Putin’s power.
articles.abstract: A new wave of news outlets has used conventional, and unconventional, methods to pierce the veil of Putin’s power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian language has introduced a few words that in recent years have been widely used and misused in English: disinformation, kompromat, Novichok.

articles.headline: Boeing Calls for Global Grounding of 777s Equipped With One Engine Model
articles.snippet: The company said 128 jets powered by a particular Pratt & Whitney engine should get inspections. Japanese regulators ordered that the planes be grounded.
articles.abstract: The company said 128 jets powered by a particular Pratt & Whitney engine should get inspections. Japanese regulators ordered that the planes be grounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Sunday that all 128 of its 777 jetliners powered by a particular Pratt & Whitney engine model should be grounded worldwide until the Federal Aviation Administration determines the best way to inspect the engines.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Ben Dooley

articles.headline: The Lost Hours: How Confusion and Inaction at the Capitol Delayed a Troop Deployment
articles.snippet: As violence grew out of control on Jan. 6, the head of the Capitol Police made an urgent request for the National Guard. It took nearly two hours to be approved.
articles.abstract: As violence grew out of control on Jan. 6, the head of the Capitol Police made an urgent request for the National Guard. It took nearly two hours to be approved.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At 1:09 p.m. on Jan. 6, minutes after protesters had burst through the barricades around the U.S. Capitol and began using the steel debris to assault the officers standing guard, the chief of the Capitol Police made a desperate call for backup. It took nearly two hours for officials to approve the deployment of the National Guard.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: Tough Sanctions, Then a Mysterious Last-Minute Turnabout
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department slapped sanctions on the Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler in 2017 for corruption in Africa. In Donald Trump’s final days in office, they were rolled back with no explanation.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department slapped sanctions on the Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler in 2017 for corruption in Africa. In Donald Trump’s final days in office, they were rolled back with no explanation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In early December, an Israeli billionaire named Dan Gertler made an unusual request to the Treasury Department.

articles.headline: Why an Animated Flying Cat With a Pop-Tart Body Sold for Almost $600,000
articles.snippet: A fast-growing market for digital art, ephemera and media is marrying the world’s taste for collectibles with cutting-edge technology.
articles.abstract: A fast-growing market for digital art, ephemera and media is marrying the world’s taste for collectibles with cutting-edge technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Fraud Checks and Errors Slow Small-Business Relief Loans
articles.snippet: The renewed Paycheck Protection Program has disbursed $140 billion this year, but many applicants have had to wait weeks for lenders to resolve problems.
articles.abstract: The renewed Paycheck Protection Program has disbursed $140 billion this year, but many applicants have had to wait weeks for lenders to resolve problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: The problems plaguing those seeking loans from the government’s revived small-business relief program have ranged from simple to shocking.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Denies Trump’s Final Bid to Block Release of Tax Returns
articles.snippet: The former president’s accountants will give New York prosecutors the financial records he has spent years trying to shield.
articles.abstract: The former president’s accountants will give New York prosecutors the financial records he has spent years trying to shield.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday rejected a last-ditch attempt by former President Donald J. Trump to shield his financial records, issuing a brief, unsigned order that ended Mr. Trump’s bitter 18-month battle to stop prosecutors in Manhattan from poring over his tax returns as they investigate possible financial crimes.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak, William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess and Benjamin Weiser

articles.headline: What’s Really Behind Corporate Promises on Climate Change?
articles.snippet: Many big businesses have not set targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Others have weak goals.
articles.abstract: Many big businesses have not set targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Others have weak goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past several years, BlackRock, the giant investment firm, has cast itself as a champion of the transition to clean energy.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Clifford Krauss
